Total global steel production is expected to grow by 30% by 2050, so understandably, there is a huge need to reduce CO2 emissions from this industry. Over the last 30 years, the steel industry has reduced energy consumption per tonne by 50%, so there are limited simple solutions available and any potential for further mitigation in CO2 emissions might not have a strong impact. The estimated CO2 emission reduction potential across the industry is approximately 27 Mt/year, which can be achieved by:
- Energy Optimizing (upgrade to newer technology to use energy more efficiently)
- Fuel Switching (using alternative cleaner, but more expensive fuel instead of coal)
- Recycling (using scrap steel as opposed to forging new steel resulting in lower grade steel)
- Training and Awareness (making companies and workers aware of the various ways to optimise use of machinery, equipment, processes and other steps to operate the production efficiently)
Some emission-reducing opportunities can be cost-effective, profitable and result in other co-benefits (better environmental compliance, health benefits, etc.).
